description: From Middle English vewe, from Anglo-Norman vewe, from Old French veue f (French vue f), feminine past participle of veoir (“to see”) (French voir). Cognate with Italian vedere, as well as Portuguese and Spanish ver. Doublet of veduta. Doublet of vista.

entries.meaning: The act of seeing or looking at something.
examples: He changed seats to get a complete view of the stage.
If there are any rabbits in this park, they keep carefully out of our view.

entries.meaning: Something to look at, such as scenery.
examples: My flat has a view of a junkyard.

entries.meaning: (Internet) An individual viewing of a web page or a video etc. by a user.
examples: Synonyms: (of a webpage) pageview, (of a video) play
[Graces] which, by the splendor of her view / Dazzled, before we never knew.

entries.meaning: A picture, drawn or painted; a sketch.
examples: a fine view of Lake George

definitionGroups.group: An opinion, judgement, imagination, idea or belief.

examples: I need more information to get a better view of the situation.

entries.meaning: A way of understanding something, an opinion, a theory.
examples: Your view on evolution is based on religious doctrines, not on scientific findings.
From my view that is a stupid proposition.
He smuggled a knife into prison with a view to using it as a weapon.

entries.meaning: (computing, databases) A virtual or logical table composed of the result set of a query in relational databases.
(computing, programming) The part of a computer program which is visible to the user and can be interacted with

verbs.description: view (third-person singular simple present views, present participle viewing, simple past and past participle viewed)

examples: The video was viewed by millions of people.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To regard in a stated way.
examples: I view it as a serious breach of trust.
